metadata.title: Title: Characterization of two novel ADP ribosylation factors from giant freshwater prawn Macrobrachium rosenbergii and their responses to WSSV challenge Detailed Response to Reviewers' Comments

abstract.text: ADP-ribosylation factors (Arfs) are small GTP-binding proteins that have an essential function in intracellular trafficking and organelle structure. To date, little information is available on the Arfs in the economically important giant freshwater prawn Macrobrachium rosenbergii and their relationship to viral infection. Here we identified two Arf genes from M. rosenbergii (MrArf1 and MrArf2) for the first time. Phylogenetic analysis showed that MrArf1, together with MjArf1 from shrimp Marsupenaeus japonicus belonged to Class I Arfs. By contrast, MrArf2 didn't not match any of the Arfs classes of I/II/III, although it could be clustered with an Arf protein from M. japonicas called MjArfn, which may represent an analog of the Arf. MrArf1 was ubiquitously expressed in all the examined tissues, with the highest transcription level in the hepatopancreas, whereas MrArf2 was only highly expressed in the hepatopancreas and exhibited very low levels in the stomach and intestines. In addition, the white spot syndrome virus (WSSV) infection model of the prawn was also established. The virus proliferated obviously in the gills and hepatopancreas 48 h after infection. The relative mRNA expressions of MrArf1 in the gills and hepatopancreas also increased significantly after WSSV challenge, and all reached the maximal level at 48 h as the same trend of WSSV proliferation. However, MrArf2 transcript showed no obvious change in the gill, but increased significantly in the hepatopancreas 24 h after infection. RNAi results showed that knockdown of MrArf1 or MrArf2 could inhibit the expression of the envelope protein gene vp28 of the WSSV. So, it could be speculated that MrArf1 and MrArf2 might facilitate WSSV infection.

We would like to resubmit our manuscript titled: Characterization of two novel ADP ribosylation factors from giant freshwater prawn Macrobrachium rosenbergii and their responses to WSSV challenge to DCI short communication. All the authors agree to the resubmission. I hope the revised MS could reach the requirement of DCI. We also responsed to the review comments and revised the MS according to the comments.

Please see my specific comments below. At present, I cannot recommend publication of this MS in the journal of Developmental & Comparative Immunology before major revisions are made.

FIGREF0.text: The results showed that MrArf1 and MrArf2 were mainly expressed in hepatopancreas. In white spot syndrome virus (WSSV) challenged shrimp, the expression level of MrArf1 was up-regulated in hepatopancreas (24 and 48 hpi) and gill (48 hpi), while the expression level of MrArf2 was only up-regulated in hepatopancreas at 24 hpi. Lastly, both MrArf1 and MrArf2 were knocked down by specific double strand RNA, and in the MrArf-silenced shrimp, the viral replication was also suppressed.

So, it could be speculated that MrArf1 and MrArf2 might play important roles 51 in the innate immune system against WSSV infection. 52 Keywords: Macrobrachium rosenbergii; ADP ribosylation factor; after its first discovery in Asia in the early 1990s, the white spot 63 syndrome virus (WSSV) developed into an epizootic disease. WSSV is currently 64 found in most crustacean farming areas in the world, where it causes large economic 65 losses to the aquaculture industry. Aside from its economic effect, the disease also 66 poses a threat to natural marine and freshwater ecology (Jiravanichpaisal et al., 2004; 67 Nambi et al., 2012). As such, understanding the molecular mechanism of the innate 68 immune defense against virus infection is imperative. Recent studies have 69 demonstrated that the small GTPases found in shrimp participate in antiviral 70 immunity by regulating phagocytosis (Liu et al., 2009; Wu et al., 2007). In Drosophila 71 S2 cells (Schneider line 2), Ran protein, a small Ras-like GTPase, was involved in the 72 regulation of phagocytosis against Drosophila C virus (DCV). Some members of the 73 ADP ribosylation factors (Arfs) found in mammals (Nie et al., 2003; D'Souza-Schorey 74 and Chavrier, 2006) and the shrimp Marsupeneaus japonicas (Wang et al., 2009; Ma 75 et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2010), which are classified with small GTP-binding proteins 76 (~ 21 kDa) involved in virus infection. The relationship between various Arfs and 77 virus invasion is thus worth investigating. 78 Arfs are small, ubiquitously expressed GTP-binding proteins best known for 79 their role in membrane trafficking (D'Souza-Schorey and Chavrier, 2006; Beck et al., 80 2011; Popoff et al., 2011; Sannerud et al., 2011) and in regulating actin cytoskeleton 81 assembly (Myers and Casanova, 2008). The six mammalian Arfs are divided into 82 three classes based on their amino-acid identity. Class I contains Arf1, Arf2, and Arf3; 83 class II contains Arf4 and Arf5; and class III contains only Arf6. Class I and class II 84 Arfs are mainly concentrated in the Golgi apparatus, although they also function in 85 endosomal compartments. By contrast, Arf6 is primarily localized in the plasma 86 membrane and is a subset of the endosomes. A large body of evidence indicates that 87 Arfs promote the biogenesis of carrier vesicles by nucleating the assembly of coat 88 protein complexes in the sites of vesicle formation (Myers and Casanova, 2008; 89 localizations and functions, which depend on the specific membrane they bind 91 according to their recruitment of diverse groups of proteins. Such specificities can be 92 defined by determining which regulators of Arfs, GEFs (guanine nucleotide-exchange 93 factors), and GAPs (GTPase-activating proteins) function with which Arf proteins Donaldson and Honda, 2005; Sun et al., 2011). The binding of Arfs to membranes 95 appears to be essential for viral replication (Belov et al., 2007a), and they cycle 96 between GTP-and GDP-bound states. In the former cycle, the activated form 97 Arf-GTP is bound to the membrane; in the latter cycle, Arf-GDP is released by the 98 cellular GTPase activity into the cytoplasm. 99 During the evolutionary interplay between virus infection and host defense, the 100 Arf-dependent secretion pathway may be involved in anti-virus action through 101 secretion of interferons and presentation of viral antigens by MHC I (Molla et al., 102 1991; Ma et al., 2010). The pathway of secretion or endocytic can easily be made to 103 cause viral immune evasion and virus propagation, and Arfs can be recruited to the 104 specific target membrane to induce disintegration of intracellular membranes and 105 formation of specific vesicles by viral proteins mediating their interactors (Belov et al., 106 2007b). Arf1 was reported to have important roles in the regulation of viral RNA 107 replication and the production of infectious hepatitis C virus (HCV), a kind of 108 plus-strand RNA virus (Matto et al., 2011). GBF1, a kind of Arf GEFs, was crucial for 109 the RNA replication of coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) (Lanke et al., 2009). In addition to 110 the function in the viral RNA replication, class II Arf proteins (Arf4 and Arf5) played 111 important roles in the secretion of dengue virus (DENV) (Kudelko et al., 2012). 112 Mouse hepatitis coronavirus (MHV) replication was dependent on the 113 GBF1-mediated Arf1 activation (Verheije et al., 2008). The replication of plant RNA 114 virus also needed the participation of Arf1 (Hyodo et al., 2013). The previous research 115 showed that Arfs were related to RNA virus replication and secretion, however, the 116 relationship between Arfs and DNA virus infection was rarely reported. WSSV is 117 a double stranded DNA virus and MjArf4 from M. japonicus was significantly 118 up-regulated with the propagation of WSSV (Zhang et al., 2010). The relatively low 119 expression level of MjArfn in WSSV-resistant shrimp may suggest its roles in WSSV invasion (Ma et al.et al., 2011; Ye et al., 2012), Arfs were rarely studied. In this 123 study, two Arf genes (MrArf1 and MrArf2) were identified from M. rosenbergii, an 124 economically important crustacean in the aquaculture industry (Mohanakumaran Nair 125 et al., 2006) for the first time. The expression level of MrArfs were up-regulated with 126 the WSSV propagation, which might preliminary indicate the roles of MrArfs , tissue collection and Immune challenge by WSSV 131 M. rosenbergii (about 15 g each) were purchased from an aquaculture market in 132 Zhenjiang, Jiangsu Province, China. The prawns were acclimatized in freshwater 133 tanks under laboratory conditions at room temperature (25 °C). The prawns were 134 divided into a control group and an experimental group designated as 135 WSSV-challenged group. The WSSV inoculum was prepared following the previous 136 paper (Wu et al., 2008). In brief, it was extracted from virus-infected M. japonicus by 137 homogenizing muscle in TN buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, 400 mM NaCl, pH 7.4). Then 138 the tissue homogenates were centrifuged at 2000 × g for 10 min. The supernatant was 139 diluted 100 times with 0.9% NaCl and was subsequently filtered through 0.45 µm 140 filter. About 100 µL of filtrate (10 5 WSSV copies/mL) was injected into the lateral 141 area of the fourth abdominal segment of the prawns using a syringe with 29-gauge 142 needle. The hepatopancreas and gills of the prawns challenged with WSSV at 0, 24, 143 and 48 h (3 prawns at each time) were collected for RNA extraction.
